text.sentence: Hi Mike,
Howdy? Just got my machine due to some scheduling issue.
Got a whole bunch of papers to read from my mentor.
Looks like I will have loads to do while I am here but she seems like a nice, enthusiastic person.
Hope your meeting with Dr. Mitra went well.
I came to know of one ML technique in which there is no need to explicitly design features.
this is what is primarily used here.
i will tell you abt this after learning more.
i was totally shocked to think this is possible but it is apparently.
more later.
yes, there are techniques in theory (like representational distortion), but I didn't know there's something in practice.
hey how was your ML presentation.
Did you fultooo impress the class :))
no man.. :( I prepared it well, but Dan, as always, vanquished me completely.
Never felt more embarrassed.. :P
I'm not complaining though, because I learnt a lot.
Just I have to be more prepared for the next class. :)
How was your first day at NEC ?
Did you get my SMS ?
Did you understand the papers ?
Just for fun, I was checking last year ICML and ACL papers.
http://www.icml2010.org/abstracts.html
http://acl2010.org/accepted_papers.html
Most of the matter went way over my head.
Looks like we have to go a lot to meet the state-of-the-art research.
Still, I'm hopeful.
As I told you many times before, I've never lost hope and I'll never do so.
And I want the same for you. :)
LOL, ok this deserves a phone call.
I will try to catch you tonight.
Thanks for the featureless learning links as well.
We should discuss this sometime.
And you are right, we have a long wayto go before catching up with the state-of-the-art ML communities.
I am getting the feeling that most breakthroughs in ML stems from trying to solve "hard" NLP tasks.
And like you said may both of us never lose hope and never stop wanting to do better. :)
looks like I'll call you, because I have a bong meeting tonight.. so I'll call you after that or maybe tomorrow morning.
Sure Mike,
have fun.
Me still at office!
And today we had one of those little meetings on the ML contest.
Dan, as he proves time and again, is really awesome.
It's totally different from the BS group meetings we used to have in the name of ChemXSeer, CiteSeer, etc.
He knows how to interest people.
I really enjoyed today's meeting.
Here also we are keeping a wiki, but nowhere like the useless one Mitraji asked us to put up.
You have to know how to use a wiki before you start using it.
Wiki is for coordination, and if there is proper coordination, you may not need it at all.
It's just a tool for helping you out, not a weekly menace that you have to report and wrap up.
And Dan showed that he is a master coordinator as well.
You can log in to the wiki using your PSU account and see:
http://wikispaces.psu.edu/display/mlchallenge/chess
I admit you may not be clear on everything but you'll get the idea.
Here five people are working on the same problem and they are updating this wiki whenever there is something new or interesting to report.
Each week we discuss on the findings of the last week and Dan puts up a modified work plan on the wiki.
You won't have to report every week, but it's like if you don't do anything, you'll feel bad.
So people are working out of their own involvement - which is crucial for something to succeed.
Unlike the case with Mitraji or Giles in a meeting.
They'll start asking if you have done something, and if you have not, you'll be chastised.
But they won't take care or responsibility of anything that was done.
Let alone be checking the wiki, which is actually pretty easy to do.
I understand your irritation with our group and the way things are done.
I think part of the reason why Dan is so good with teaching/coordination is perhaps due to his
own experience at Cornell.
I guess when you are exposed to good stuff during your own time you tend to be more benevolent when you can be.
Like today, we had an all girls lunch at NEC.

I was hearing the conversation of two ladies who got their phds from CMUs and they were going gaga abt how great CMU is and how it feels to be in the midst of geniuses both professors and students there.
They were saying that it is not just being smart, most of the success comes from hardwork and the conducive environment that surrounds you.
Anyway one lady who got her Phd in 1994 is currently the head of some group here and her words to me were "the trick is you don't give up".
As long as you dont give up you will be fine.
I was so impressed that a person of such stature was so modest and down-to-earth.
These are the people who I cannot help but admire.
Apparently Sean Hallgren was here for a few years and Swarat was here for a postdoc before he became a professor. :)
And Dr. Giles ko tho sab jaante hai.
My mentor was like he did some great stuff at NEC, I dont know why he totally changed tracks :D
well, yeah, you are right.
And another reason is - I just thought about it today - look, there are 13 people in our group.
As we know, union is strength.
So many people can do lots of good stuff, *provided* they are collaborating instead of competing.
What I mean is, instead of everybody working on different problems and going nowhere, why not take 4 people together and let them pursue the same problem.
In this way, may be 3 problems will be solved by 12 people, but the time taken will be less and the quality of output will be high.
Say, for example, the TREC thing. Although the data didn't come, we progressed a lot in our thoughts.
That was possible because 3 people - you, me and Sumit - also Mitraji - was working for the SAME problem.
I am sure if that thing works out, it will be good.
But there are two preconditions:
1> The coordinator has to be knowledgeable and practical - not a whimsical fellow like Giles or Mitraji

2> You are allowed to pursue at max 2 problems at a time - one problem is with the group (with weekly meetings and wiki), and another problem is between you and your advisor. And the former is mandatory.
I think this model, if properly implemented, might have resulted in an ICML or NIPS within a reasonable amount of time.
